author: James Allen, High School Spotlight
title: Runner seasoned beyond her years
text:
Colonie's Kathryn Tenney, center, gets a hug from her coach Frank... Runner seasoned beyond her years 1 / 1 Back to Gallery 
Kathryn Tenney, just a freshman, is in her third year as a member of the Colonie girls' varsity cross country team. 
Saturday, Tenney won the Division II race at the Grout Run in Schenectady's Central Park — registering the fastest time of the day among Section II competitors in 15 minutes, 24.5 seconds. 
Q: How do you feel the season has gone so far? 
A: My team has been doing very well with a 7-0 streak and personally, I have been doing pretty well. 
Q: Did you enter the season with a level of expectation regarding your individual results? 
A: I just wanted to set as many personal records on as many courses as I could. This is a TU+ story. Click for more information. 
Q: Is there a particular course you really enjoy running on more than the others? 
A: One of my favorites is at Queensbury, but we haven't run there since I was in seventh grade. This season, we're running at (Guilderland's) Tawasentha Park. That is my favorite course. 
Q: How would you describe Saturday's performance at the Grout Run? 
A: I don't know if I was expecting to win, but I did want to get a faster time than last year. That was my goal. 
Q: Were you surprised when you finished the race and it took a while for teammate Amanda Chambers to cross the line in second place? 
A: Usually, I will turn around at some point to see if anyone is near me. This time, I didn't. I was pretty surprised. 
Q: You have some big races upcoming before sectionals. Do you think you can make the state meet this year? 
A: I think I have a chance. I would like to make it to the states because I never have before. I know my teammates have before. I think I am good enough to make it there. 
Q: It is a long way off, but would you like to run in college? 
A: Yes, I would take that under consideration if I get that chance. I am also a basketball player, too. 
Q: You have won a lot of races this season. Is that what you expected? 
A: My main thing was to set as many personal bests as I could. 
Q: Does the break in your running schedule with basketball help you? 
A: Basketball is different. I don't know. I am the only one on the cross country team that doesn't run all three seasons, so I do think it helps me. 
Q: Running in Section II is a pretty special experience with so many top teams. Does that bring out the competitiveness in you? 
A: I am a really competitive person. Anyone that I see near me in a race, I work to get myself up there. 
Honor roll 
A look at this past week's top performers: 
Julia Flower, Schalmont girls' cross country: The senior won the Class C race at the Grout Run on Saturday in 15:48.22. 
Maryanna Lansing, Shaker girls' cross country: The senior was denied a fifth Grout Run victory in the Division I event, but still managed to finish third in 15:43.82. 
Paul Nichols, Shaker boys' cross country: Claimed victory in the Division I race at the Grout Run, crossing the line in 13:34.68. 
Dawson Homer, Bethlehem boys' cross country: The junior won the Division II race at the Grout Run in 13:49.00. 
Elise Zwicklbauer, Burnt Hills field hockey: In three victories, Zwicklbauer tallied seven goals and four assists for the Spartans (11-1 overall, 10-0 Suburban Council) — pushing her season totals to 17 goals and 14 assists. 
Kelly Barkevich, Shenendehowa field hockey: Barkevich, who is also a standout softball player who just made an oral commitment to play at UAlbany, scored with 4:04 remaining Wednesday to help the Plainsmen edge Saratoga 1-0. 
Colin McLean, Shaker boys' volleyball: Tallied 22 kills, 23 assists and eight aces in a 3-2 decision over Guilderland and delivered 22 kills, 14 aces, 11 assists and nine digs in a 3-2 victory against Colonie. 
Aaron Carrk, Bethlehem boys' volleyball: Registered 21 kills Friday as the Eagles defeated Shenendehowa 3-1 in Suburban Council action. 
Chris Hamilton, Schalmont boys' soccer: The senior star scored the 100th goal of his career Tuesday as the Sabres blanked Cobleskill 13-0. 
Shane Wenz, Ichabod Crane boys' soccer: Tallied three goals Saturday to lead the Riders past Albany Academy 3-1 in the Colonial Council. 
Matt Crisafulli, Christian Brothers Academy boys' soccer: His goal in the 51st minute Thursday allowed the Brothers to edge Niskayuna 1-0 in Suburban Council action. 
Tyler Ward, Fort Ann boys' soccer: Matched a school record with six goals in a 14-0 triumph over Hartford. 
Thomas Seeberger, Loudonville Christian boys' soccer: Scored five goals in a 7-1 verdict over New Lebanon and four goals and one assist in a 7-1 win against Berlin. 
Lexi Potter, South Glens Falls girls' soccer: Scored with 11 minutes left Saturday to lift the Bulldogs past Mohonasen 1-0 
Nate Stillson, Mohonasen football: The Mighty Warriors' quarterback rushed for five touchdowns, returned an interceptions 73 yards for a touchdown and connected with Joseph Galusha on a TD pass in a 48-28 Southeast Division win over Bishop Maginn. 
Bryan Stanavich, Amsterdam football: The senior running back carried the ball 17 times for 225 yards and three touchdowns, and added a receiving touchdown in leading the Rugged Rams to a 47-13 win against Niskayuna. 
Carl Fiore, Shenendehowa football: A senior running back, Fiore carried 17 times for 215 yards and three touchdowns to help the Plainsmen produce a 42-7 Empire Division victory against Ballston Spa. 
Jacob Henes, Mechanicville football: The senior scored the first three touchdowns for the Red Raiders (runs covering 65 and 14 yards and a 65-yard reception), booted four PAT kicks, scored a two-point conversion, stopped a two-point conversion and added two interceptions in a 36-20 decision over Stillwater in the Indian Bowl. 
Mike Brandow, Greenwich football: Rushed for 150 yards and three touchdowns to help the Witches post a 28-13 North Division victory over Corinth. 
Daryl Hillman, Whitehall football: The junior ran for 251 yards and four touchdowns, helping the Railroaders beat AuSable Valley 41-0. 
Wyatt Cushman, Hoosick Falls football: Connected with Connor McCart on touchdown passes covering 25 and 39 yards, plus ran for two touchdowns, as the Panthers posted a 47-13 victory against Holy Trinity. 
Team of the week 
Shenendehowa field hockey: Led by standouts Emily Fraser and Kelly Barkevich, the Plainsmen defeated Saratoga (1-0) and Shaker (2-0) to improve to 9-1 overall.
